body: Testing general comment.

Please note - the requirement is to have the word "incubating" in the source release.  There is no requirement that the version # has to include "incubating" but most people find this the easiest way to handle it.  It has the downside that your convenience binaries now unnecessarily include "-incubating" in them.

Regarding the "-incubating" comment in the version, I was just following what other projects seemed to do. If it's only required in the source release, I'd probably prefer to not include it in the version. It added a little extra complexity and makes the version numbers a bit messy.

I'd really like to schedule this change specifically. I.e., coordinate so all outstanding work is committed, then this change occurs. Because I have outstanding changes that include removal and renaming of files, movement of code from class to class and file to file. 

Past experience has told me that major rename/relabel events need to happen without putting a huge burden on those with major sets of outstanding changes. 

In other words. I'd like 60 days notice before this happens.
Seems reasonable. I'll close this pull request and create a new one that just adds the Apache incubator stuff and a few other minor things, plus addresses the comments in this thread.
Not merging. This was a test pull request.

Note for reviewers, much of the diff is due to indentation caused by the new try/catch block. It might be easier to view this change via `git log -p -1 ae518d6c5e5f9` to ignore the whitespace changes.

VMF works - it was failing for lack of a -Xss3M JVM parameter. We need 3M stacks for these larger schemas.

With a tiny change (which is backward compatible to Daffodil 2.0.0) Link16 also works. So I think now all schemas work.

It would be nice if there was a commit message that explained the changes, and what was wrong with the previous code. It makes sense after looking at it, but I had to look up what NoText meant and look at other piecese of code to get an idea of what was broken and how it was fixed. A nice commit message would have made it easier.
+1 for new changes
Closing. Not setup properly.
That's because I added a disclaimer file, and so did Steve on latest master. So this conflict has popped up since his latest push. I'll drop the file from mine.

Suggested approach:

Start with the file FormatInfo.scala (in daffodil-io). Then look at the changes to daffodil-io, where many operations are now passed a FormatInfo. Then look at the runtime changes.
Please put the discussion above into a comment in the TDML test case(s). This point is too subtle to lose in a review.

Actually, I think some of the discussion above in the first paragraph belongs in comments in the code that make the intent of the algorithm clearer. You added a few comments, but I think they should be expanded. The things you mention above as "that code is correct" ,... well it is not at all clear from the code that this is the intent of the algorithm.

The top comment is the commit message so it won't be lost. I agree that more comments are needed to describe this logic--it isn't trivial logic. I think the discussion about what the bug is belongs in the commit message, but what the correct logic is makes sense to be in the code. I'll add that. I think the TDML comment should just describes what the test tests, so I /think/ that's sufficient with good code comments.

Will modify to improve comments. No changes changes will be made.

More thorough testing: 

3 tests fail in daffodil-cli, 
PCAP one test fails (test_pcap_test_http_ipv6), 
LInk16 gets bitOrder bugs (related to DAFFODIL-1843 I think), 
VMF test_K02_10 gets stack overflow in DFDL schema compiler, and test_K07_1,  4, 7, 8, 9 and test1_K07_1 all also fail with similar bitOrder problem.
General observation regarding your comments about the += vs append(), should these insights be added to the wiki for best practices and optimizations?

Definitely. These types of things are not obvious and really take profiling and digging into Scala library code to figure out what is going on.

We also have a handful of things in Daffodil to improve performance (e.g. Maybe, Pools, ThreadLocal) that would be good to document in a "Coding for Performance" type of section on the wiki.

This same flag - about whether an element appears in expressions, can be used to shut off the length-capture processors - 4 are generally used: captureContentStart, captureValueStart, captureValueEnd, CaptureContentEnd. That's a lot of overhead if the length functions that use the values from these aren't being called.

I think we already have logic to remove those processor when elements are not used in value/conentLength expressions. However, it is done differently than this and not using this flag since the logic is only needed when creating the parser/unparsers. It isn't needed at runtime like this flag is.

Related, one side effect of how the content/valueLength stuff works now is you can only get the content/valueLength of something used in an expression, since the parsers/unparsers are laid down to capture that information only when it might be needed. So things like debuggers cannot use this information on arbitrary elements.

So it might be worth it to remove the capture processors completely and use this new flag (or something similar, I don't think it can be exactly the same) at runtime in the appropriate processors to determine when to capture length. And when debugging, we would just always capture the length of everything. This would mean there might be some added overhead to constantly check this flag (which will most often be false) to see if we need to capture length, but one boolean check shouldn't be too bad.

That said, this seems like an enhancement that I'm not sure is a high priority right now. We already have the optimization to remove unneeded capture length parsers, which I think is the important part of this conversation.
Remember to use DAFFODIL-XXXX instead of DFDL-XXXX for bug numbers in the comment.
Remember to use DAFFODIL-XYZ instead of DFDL-XYZ in the commit message.
+1 to latest batch of changes

+1

Regarding the scallop library, the issue is likely that the daffodil-cli subproject is not aggregated into the root project. So any command you run on the root (e.g. sbt compile, sbt test, sbt updateClassifiers) will also run on all subprojects ***except*** the daffodil-cli subproject. To run a command on the daffodil-cli subproject you must explicitly specify it. This prevents running all the CLI tests (which take a long time) when you run ``sbt test``. So in addition to running ``sbt updateClassifiers`` you also need to run ``sbt daffodil-cli/updateClassifiers``. This should be added to our eclipse set up documentation.
Ooops. created incorrectly.

+1

Nothing jumped out at me as being an issue.
Just realized I totally forgot to test things once I rebased on master before pushing my branch up.  Currently broken as the getByteArray method now needs a FormatInfo object.  Will push up fix soon.
See PR 26, which is changes since these review comments. Due to rebase, those changes couldn't be on this same branch or this comment history would be overwritten and lost. Hence, the new PR.
The TravisCI buidl failed, maybe eclipse can't detect certain errors? Try building in SBT and see if you get the errors.

Is it not an issue that one of the unparser tests fails?  The delimited packed sequence unparser tests fail because it unparses "3" as "3C" instead of "003C".  Is this an issue?  If it isn't, should I just remove the unparser tests?

If I understand BCD correctly, 3<sub>10</sub> = 0x3C<sub>BCD</sub>. Since minLength defaults to zero if not supplied, if will unparse to the minimum number of bytes needed, which is just 0x3C. If you had minLength="2" on the other hand, then it should pad 0x3C to 2 bytes, in which case I would expect 0x003C.

So I think the test just needs to be updated to either specify minLength or to not expect the zeros (or maybe add some extra tests so both cases are covered). Same thing applies for the DelimitedPackedDecSeq test which uparses 0.03.

I'm not sure minLength is the solution.  First off, I don't think you can specify xs:minLength on an xs:int or xs:decimal.  Also, what is really weird is that BCD and IBM4690 don't seem to have an issue and somewhere along the way the 00 (or FF in IBM4690) is getting added.  I'm not sure where they are coming from as the minLengthInBits parameter that is getting passed into the *fromBigInteger functions is always 0 and the functions output a byte array that is just [3].  So I'm not sure how this works for BCD and IBM4690 and I'm even more confused why the same thing isn't happening for packed.

I found the section I think you were talking about with not padding anything:
section 12.3.2    dfdl:lengthKind 'delimited'
 - "When unparsing a simple element with binary representation, then for hexBinary the length is the number of bytes in the infoset value padded to the XSD minLength facet value using dfdl:fillByte, and for the other types the length is the minimum number of bytes to represent the value and any sign."

So it sounds like instead of the bug is actually in the BCD and IBM4690 unparsers that were padding the data, not Packed.  Also, your understanding of BCD is different than mine.  I thought that BCD doesn't have sign nibbles, ie. the decimal number 3 would just be 0x03, not 0x3C.  Packed uses sign nibbles and would be represented 0x3C.

Ok, so fatherhood has not been kind to my powers of observation.  The reason that the BCD and IBM4690 unparser tests were passing when I expected them to fail was due to the fact that I labeled them with tdml:parserTestCase instead of tdml:unparserTestCase.

I have fixed these tests and updated the delimited parsers for all 3 formats to no longer take a minimum bit length parameter.
This will be the last commit before 2.1.0-rc1 is created. Will hold off merging until all other pull requests are merged.
Josh, did you mean to close this? Looks like this was never merged.
I could have sworn that I pushed rebase & merge, let me try again.
Note, this is for DAFFODIL-1896. Need to fixup commit message.
This thing was driving me crazy with wasted time working on even modest size schemas. Turns out it was pretty easy to fix.
+1, but should we hold off the merge until after 2.1.0 is released?

I concur that we should not merge until after 2.1.0 is released, assuming no other patches. This fix would be for NATO, so I'm not thrilled that there are known issues bothering them and that we release anyway, but this particular issue, the right fix for it isn't 100% clear to me. So I think we have to delay it.
Review comment changes applied. 3 commits squashed into 1.
This will be merged as a part of PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-daffodil/pull/49
Squashed 3 commits into 1 before merging.

I have tested this version with sbt test, sbt it:test, and I have tested all DFDLSchemas and FOUO schemas. All passes on my workstation. I have verified that eclipse is also working properly and one can run Daffodil's tests there, and tests of the various DFDL schemas there.
I just pushed up a few more changes with a couple added tests demonstrating what works and what doesn't work with our current implementation of separatorSuppressionPolicy trailing.

Seems like a spurious error from the Travis build.  The Travis build failed right away in code that wasn't touched at all (DaffodilTunables.scala).  Not sure what is going on with it, but it builds and tests just fine on my system.
Created this wrong. Closing.
Nevermind. Broken idea.
Closing as this is expected behavior.
Ah, Travis found some regressions I missed. So this will be revised.
+1 with recent changes

Turns out the new Scallop version broke some CLI tests, primarily due to ambiguities with the --validate option. Updated scallop hoping it would fix it, but it didn't. So added a commit which changes how the --validate option works, the 'mode' parameter is now required. This prevents ambiguities where the thing following --validate could be either a validate option or the input file. Now a mode *must* follow the --validate option. This breaks backwards compatibility, but is pretty minor.
Note that the Travis CI build failure appears to be an out of memory error, which is fixed by bumping up the memory in PR #78.
I realized that the LICENSE and eclipse classpath files needed to be updated to the new scala and scallop versions. Just added a commit that fixes those.

I was imagining we we still support both 2.11 and 2.12 (e.g. we will publish both versions to maven), but default to 2.12 for development and the binary CLI release. If upgrading eclipse to 2.12, we can revert the eclipse config changes and document that eclipse users should run the following command to build the 2.11 version libraries:
```
sbt "++2.11.12" "updateClassifiers"
```
The ++ command switches the default scala version so that updateClassifiers builds the 2.11 versions. Or we could change it so the default is still 2.11, but 2.12 is still supported. Both versions are tested in travis, so it probably doesn't really matter too much what the default is. Though, I imagine 2.11 is going to be EOLed at some point, so we should at least start thinking about making 2.12 the default.
Release Audit Tool. It's usually run by incubator mentors/voters during releases to make sure there aren't incorrectly licensed files. But with this we can now check it continually for every change.

Can you modify the commit message to include some of the information in the PR message? Alot of that would be useful to have, especially the descriptions of simple vs twoPass etc.
That would also be good to have on the [TDML page](https://daffodil.apache.org/tdml).

I will update the commit message so that it is formatted correctly and with more detail.  Should I amend the commit and force push it and then add follow up commits for the necessary code changes?

You are correct that the bug describes implementing the fourth combination of bit+byte order, but after discussing the problem with Mike on the list (https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/99bcd6fe3d75fbcaa70413ee643b7d3ce247260dc0224a78dc45bd23@%3Cdev.daffodil.apache.org%3E) we both concluded that this approach would be simpler and would achieve the desired support.

We've found that amend and --force commits have caused old review comments to disappear from GitHub sometimes, so we tend to avoid it. The recommended way to add changes to a review is to make new commits with --fixup or --squash options. --squash with --allow-empty is a good way to create a new commit message if no actual changes are needed.

Once you get two +1's, you can rebase -i and squash/fixup everything into a single commit, do a force push, and then we'll merge the change.
I forget the actual numbers, but it was pretty substantial, in the order of hundreds of megabytes of  allocations that are avoided.
+1. If you now squash your changes into a single commit and --force commit, it'll be good to merge. Thanks!
I squashed my commits and rebased on master.
Merged. Thanks for you contribution!

All could be easily code generated from a list that just contains the name of the tunable option, its type, and default value. That's another thing we might want to do from propgen.
